questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an additive primary color?
What colors are combined to create white light in an additive color system?
What happens to light that is absorbed by an object?
Which part of the eye is responsible for focusing light onto the retina?
Which cells in the retina are responsible for detecting color?
The primary subtractive colors are red, blue, and green.
The cornea is responsible for most of the eyeâ€™s refraction.
Rods are more sensitive to light than cones.
The optic nerve creates a blind spot in the eye.
Explain the difference between additive and subtractive color mixing.
questions.answer: Additive color mixing combines light sources (red, green, blue) to make white. Subtractive mixing combines pigments (cyan, magenta, yellow) to absorb light and create black.

questions.question: If you shine a blue light on a yellow object, what color will the object appear and why?
questions.answer: It will appear black or dark because yellow pigment absorbs blue light and reflects red and green light, but since the blue light source provides no red or green, no light is reflected.

questions.question: Describe the pathway light follows from the cornea to the optic nerve.
questions.answer: Light enters through the cornea, passes through the aqueous humor, pupil, lens, vitreous humor, and is focused onto the retina. The optic nerve then transmits signals to the brain.
